steps.title: Make your CPU work for some time without producing any noticeable event.
steps.content: Make your CPU work for some time without producing any noticeable event.

steps.title: Do no other operation during that delay, in order to create a simple time-delay.
steps.content: Do no other operation during that delay, in order to create a simple time-delay.

steps.title: Use a typical "for" loop followed by a null statement to implement time delay.
steps.content: Use a typical "for" loop followed by a null statement to implement time delay.

steps.title: Write as follows, for an example:
steps.content: Write as follows, for an example: for (i=1 ; i<100 ; i++) ; The statement followed by the ";" makes the computer execute the loop 100 times without any noticeable event. It just creates a time delay.

steps.title: Use sleep() The function called sleep(int ms) declared in <TIME.H>which makes the program wait for the time in milliseconds specified.
steps.content: Use sleep() The function called sleep(int ms) declared in <TIME.H>which makes the program wait for the time in milliseconds specified.

steps.title: Include the following line in your program before "int main()":
steps.content: Include the following line in your program before "int main()": #include <TIME.H>

steps.title: Insert, wherever you need your program to make a delay:
steps.content: Insert, wherever you need your program to make a delay: sleep(1000); Change the "1000" to the number of milliseconds you want to wait (for example, if you want to make a 2 second delay, replace it with "2000". Tip: On some systems the value might refer to seconds, instead of milliseconds. So sometimes 1000 isn't one second, but, in fact, 1000 seconds.
